Award.AwardTitle: A Mechanistic Model for the Evolution of the Vertebrate Head Skeleton
Award.AbstractNarration: Vertebrates evolved from small filter-feeding worms around a half-billion years ago. The vertebrate subphylum has since become one of the most widespread animal groups, giving rise to a stunning diversity of species, including humans. One of the keys to vertebrate success is the robust and highly adaptable vertebrate head skeleton. Despite the central role of the head skeleton in vertebrate evolution very little is known about how it first formed. This project uses modern molecular methods to address this long-standing and previously intractable question by analyzing the genetic mechanisms underlying skeletal development in three key species. The first animal, amphioxus, is an invertebrate regarded as a 'living fossil' highly similar to the worm-like ancestor of the vertebrates. While previously thought to lack a vertebrate-type skeletal tissue, we have found exciting evidence that such tissue may form during its larval phase. The second, the lamprey, is a living representative of the most ancient vertebrate group, the agnathans. The third, the African clawed frog, is an easily accessible model vertebrate with a head skeleton similar to our own. By the novel application of modern molecular methods to the embryos and larvae of these animals, we are elucidating the genetic and developmental changes driving the evolution of the vertebrate head. In the process, the work provides training for a postdoctoral scholar, graduate, and several undergraduate students, as well as hands-on research experiences for high school students. The project also provides an opportunity for undergraduates to participate directly in novel basic research through an upper division lab course. Finally, the results of the work will be incorporated into the curriculum of a large general biology course and widely disseminated to the public through a traveling exhibit at the University of Colorado Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

 

Vertebrates are one of the most successful animal groups on the planet.  This success was made possible by the evolution of the vertebrate head skeleton, which protects the brain, and supports the sensory, feeding, respiratory organs of the head. This project has deepened our understanding of how the vertebrate head skeleton first evolved, how it forms during development, and how it diversified in early vertebrates. Specifically, it showed, for the first time, that the tissue which builds the embryonic head skeleton of vertebrates likely originated in early invertebrate chordates around 500 million years ago.  Thus, a critical step in the evolution of vertebrates was the repurposing of this ancient tissue to form the vertebrate skull.  The work also showed how this tissue was first organized into a complete head skeleton in early jawless vertebrates, and points to how this structure may have been modified to form the skull of modern jawed vertebrates. These findings fill major gaps in our understanding of how invertebrate worms evolved into vertebrates during the Cambrian period. It also provides additional insights into the genes that drive skeletal tissue development in all vertebrate, including humans. From a technical standpoint, the work has validated a powerful new method for genome editing in the fish and amphibians, and advanced methods for culturing the invertebrate chordate amphioxus through metamorphosis.

 

Broader impacts

 

The project supported the training of three biology Ph.D. students, a postdoctoral fellow, in modern molecular biology, developmental biology, evolutionary biology, and genome editing methods.  It also provided 6 undergraduates, including two women and a member of an underrepresented minority, with hands-on laboratory experience in a modern developmental genetics laboratory.  It also supported the development of new laboratory curriculum for an upper-division course that exposes undergraduates to modern developmental and genetic methods like in situ hybridization, embryo injection,  transgenesis, and genome editing.   Furthermore, it supported the construction of a traveling museum exhibit about animal genetics, development, and evolution, and accompanying public lectures by the PI.
